Service Details: Students will begin the course in the classroom learning safety and best practices for the job site, then begin working on hands-on projects individually and as a team covering trades such as carpentry/joinery, plumbing, electrical, automotive, heavy mechanical and weldingStudents will:- Gain practical and theoretical experience in a wide variety of trades - Receive direct knowledge required to make an informed decision about which trade to enter - Learn how to secure employment and training - Obtain industry knowledge from industry mentors and guest speaker - OFA 1 certification - CSTS certificationUpon completion of the program students can seek direct entry into employment and apprenticeship or enter a Foundation training program Women in Trades sponsorship funding for trades Foundation training programs may cover tuition and associated fees, books, tools (if applicable), and personal protective equipment
Eligibility: Unemployed or underemployed individuals (ineligible to receive EI benefits) with a genuine  interest in exploring trades
How to Apply: Please call the Women in Trades office
Cost: Sponsorship for course fee and materials are covered for students eligible and selected by funding through the Canada-British Columbia Labour Market Agreement
